title-group.article-title: How Much Did Working Wives Contribute to Changes in Income Inequality between Couples in the UK?

Married couples that reported negative amounts of any type of factor income (in practice, this was on earnings and investment income) were dropped from the sample. The top percentile of married couples were also dropped from the sample since their incomes were very much out of line with the rest of the sample.

It is interesting to note that there appears to be discontinuity between 1989 and 1990, with a drop of three percentage points in the proportion of single-earner couples and a corresponding rise in the proportion of two-earner couples. Furthermore, this discontinuity is in spite of the adjustment made for the potential under-reporting, prior to 1990, of childless, cohabiting couples (who are also likely to be dual-earner couples) by the FES.

This last result can be compared with that of other studies. Both Cancian, Danziger and Gottschalk (1993) and Machin and Waldfogel (1994) measured the impact of wives' earnings on family income inequality by comparing the actual distribution of family income with what it would have been had wives' earnings been set to zero. For the US, Cancian et al. found that, over 1968-88, wives' earnings reduced inequality (as measured by the square of the coefficient of variation) by about 20 per cent. For Britain, Machin and Waldfogel concluded that wives' earnings reduced inequality by about 27 per cent in 1989-90.
